utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
I'm going to wedge myself into your life then.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Mic check, one, two.
Good.
Are you good?
Yup.
All right.
First tell me a little bit about your schedule change here.
You got to go back...
Yeah.
Tell me about the vote on Iraq and what it is.
The vote is on the - it's called omnibus.
There's Spradling with Senator John McCain.
But all the candidates eventually end up in front of Spradling's microphone.
That's because WMUR is the only statewide television station in New Hampshire.
And Spradling is such a fixture on the campaign trail, odds are he's seen some telling little moments.
Like Mitt Romney in a diner swiping a piece of toast off an abandoned plate; Rudy Giuliani griping about people selling his autographed baseballs on eBay.
Then there's the blue-collar test.
And that test is very simple.
When the candidate comes into the room, they always come over and shake my hand.
The question is, do they go over to the videographer and shake his or her hand?
If they do, that person just passed the so-called blue-collar test.
If not, the shooters feel like they know a whole lot about that person before he or she ever opens their mouth.
So let's see how some of the candidates have done this cycle.
Mike Huckabee is very good at it.
Hillary Clinton is very good at it.
John Edwards is quite good at it.
Barack Obama can be a hit or a miss, but can - he's pretty consistent.
Fred Thompson.
He's failed a lot of tests.
But Fred Thompson has definitely failed the blue-collar test more than once.
In a certain way, the whole New Hampshire primary is like the blue-collar test.
Voters here listen to the candidates talk, but as important, they're watching their behavior for unscripted moments when a candidate slips and actually reveals something about themselves.
And those moments can make or break them.
Republican Ron Paul's noticed it.
He says New Hampshire voters expect the candidate to engage on a very personal level.
I'm not a very good campaigner.
I don't like to interrupt people.
That's my libertarian nature.
In some states, you know, they might not like to be bothered or interrupted, but here they almost look up and they're expecting you to interrupt them and they want you to say hello.
And if they don't know you, they want to know you.
And I think it's distinctly different from every place that I've campaigned.
By the time primary day rolls around, you'll have heard this a million times: New Hampshire voters take their first-in-the-nation primary status very, very seriously.
Lifelong Granite Stater Doris Nizbeth(ph) learned that just how seriously a few years ago.
She was with her dad in a hospital room.
His Alzheimer's had taken a toll.
But on this night she saw a glint of something.
He was sort of with it.
So we're watching this and eating Cheetos and he says, baby, I need you to make me a promise.
Now, I'm thinking he's going to ask me take care of mama.
So I said, anything, daddy.
And he holds my hand and says you have to promise me never to change your party affiliation.
And I thought it was funny and I'm sure it was partly the Alzheimer's, but you know, he just seemed so clear that night.
I didn't know, it was huge.
I guess it was a huge thing because he was talking to me to - really to me.
Sorry, I'm getting all teary-eyed.
Anyways, truth be told, I'm - hope my mother's not listening - I'm probably more of a Democrat than I am a Republican.
Are you thinking about breaking your promise?
No, I'm not breaking my promise.
I'm just thinking about trading with my husband.
I'll vote for the Republican candidate he likes if he votes for the Democratic candidate I like.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Last stop, the Barley house in Concord.
They've got the perfect thing to wash down a political tour.
Where did you have a campaign trail out (unintelligible) trail.
Who's buying?
I know I need one.
For NPR News, I'm Dan Gorenstein in Concord, New Hampshire.
Brian Duffy.
He is the editorial cartoonist for the Des Moines Register.
And the same goes for bodies of water, the same goes for highways that may, you know, freeways, that may be stopping you from walking a very short distance.
But you can't get from here to there because of a freeway.
I, something on this list puzzles me.
Los Angeles is more walkable than Portland, Oregon?
Portland is famous for its high self-regard about people's ability to get around that city in a humane way.
Well, Los Angeles is, believe it or not, one of the most dense cities in the country.
While it's not been planned to be walkable, there are historical relics of walkability in the city of Los Angeles.
And the development over the last ten years has increased its walkability.
And, finally, what you've done in southern California in general, but Los Angeles in particular, is that you are beginning to put back in your rail transit system.
Chris, you're a land-use strategist.
You consult with developers, you've worked as a developer in your past.
How is the price of gas changing the way developers are thinking, and maybe boosting this walkability idea?
It is accelerating an underlying market trend.
My research shows, others' research shows that anywhere from 30 to 50 percent of households want to live in a walkable urban place.
In most metropolitan areas, it's no more than five or ten percent supply.
So you've got this high demand and low supply, and prices go out of sight, which is what we've seen throughout the country and great concern about gentrification.
Chris Leinberger, he's a land-use strategist currently at the Brookings Institution.
His book on urban development, ""The Option of Urbanism,"" was published this year.
Chris Leinberger, thank you.
Thank you very much.
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
The Iowa caucus is just over a month away.
Yesterday, Democratic White House hopefuls went toe-to-toe in a national debate.
NPR News and Iowa Public Radio hosted the event.
It was old school - no TV cameras, no large studio audience, just the candidates sitting around a table and tackling some tough issues.
Michele Norris co-hosts NPR's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
She co-moderated the debate and gave me an insider's look at how things unfolded.
I asked her why only three topics were covered - Iran, China and immigration.
From the beginning, we decided that it would be a good idea to try to go deep, to just focus on three topics.

And we wanted to make sure that one of them dealt with national security, but the candidates have had so many opportunities to chew on Iraq that we wanted to look down the road a little bit, and look at the next challenge - some would say the next threat - and so we chose Iran.
Who knew, weeks ago, when we decided to focus on Iran, that it would just happen to be the day after the National Intelligence Estimate just happened to surface.
So, you know, the news gods smiled on us in that regard.
Well, let's hear a little bit about what you were able to wrangle out of the candidates.
The candidates, all passionate about the Iran controversy, seemed to agree that President Bush is taking the wrong approach, but they did differ in other ways.
None of us is advocating a rush to war, and I think that we have two different ways of approaching this.
Our goals are the same - diplomatic engagement with Iran.
By the way, terminology matters.
I'm a great admirer of Senator Clinton.
It's not about not advocating the rush to war, I'm advocating no war.
That was Senator Biden.
He has been framed in many ways during different debates as being strong on foreign policy.
What do you think of the exchange that he had with Senator Clinton?
Well, you know, they had a very different approach here on this.
And Senator Clinton was a bit more hawkish on this discussion.

Senator Biden, you know, was saying that the administration was completely wrong on this and that it was, you know, time to really just sort of pull back, you know, stop talking about sanctions; stop all this saber rattling.
I think there was a - I think we heard him say that three or four times in the course of the debate.
It was a bit of a retrospective conversation, though.
I mean, they were looking ahead, but they were also looking back and justifying various positions that they had taken; various votes that they had taken.

The only thing that I thought was really interesting in this debate was the pivot at one point in the second segment of that section into the discussion of Israel and how Israel plays into this, and how Muslim countries - what they hear from the current administration and also from the Congress when they talk about Middle East policy in general, and the belief among many Muslim countries that the U.S.
always favors Israel at all cost, and the price that the U.S.
pays for that, and how the U.S.

can hope to gain some diplomatic footing or deal with some of these countries as an equal partner in an honest way, if there is a belief that everything that we do is - seemed to be weighted toward providing some sort of security or benefit to our Israeli partners - our Israeli allies.
China, another huge issue as well as a huge nation, and the main phrase that kept coming up was leverage.
And Senator Obama used the term - and this was the section that you were the main facilitator for - to talk about how the U.S.
could lose influence based on the shape of our economy.
Our leverage is weakening when we run up enormous deficits funding a war that should have never been authorized.
And we then have taken out the credit card with the Chinese; that gives us less leverage.
So he's basically arguing in the rest of the debate that China is not an enemy but a competitor.
How do you think that whole idea of enemy-competitor-friend played out between the different candidates?
